sen.j: 尾張 大隅（おわり の おおすみ、生没年不明）は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: OWARI no Osumi (尾張大隅, date of birth and death unknown) is a Japanese who lived in Asuka period.
OWARI no Osumi (date of birth and death unknown) lived in the Asuka period of Japan.
OWARI no Osumi (date of birth and death unknown) lived in the Asuka period of Japan.
The clan is also written as 尾治.
His family name Owari (尾張) was also written as 尾治 (the pronunciation was the same).
His family name Owari (尾張) was also written as 尾治 (the pronunciation was the same).

sen.j: 旧仮名遣いでの読みは「をはりのおほすみ」。
sen.e: The reading in old Japanese syllabary characters is 'OHARI no Ohosumi.'
According to the old Japanese syllabary characters, it is considered that his name had been pronounced as 'Wofari no Ofosumi.'
sen.cmt: 誤訳です。飛鳥時代はw,fの音が発音されていたので「wofari no ofosumi」となります。オリジナル著者がこの文を入れたのは発音の違いを示すためです。「旧仮名遣いでの」という説明はこの著者以外使わないと思われますが、正しく訳すと左のようになります。
sen.e: According to the old Japanese syllabary characters, it is considered that his name had been pronounced as 'Wofari no Ofosumi.'

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）は連、後に宿禰。
sen.e: His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji, and shifted to Sukune later.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji, and shifted to Sukune later.
His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji, and shifted to Sukune later.

sen.j: 672年の壬申の乱のとき、大海人皇子（天武天皇）に私宅を提供した。
sen.e: During the Jinshin War in 672, he provided Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) his private house.
During the Jinshin War in 672, he provided Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) his private house.
During the Jinshin War in 672, he provided Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) his private house.
Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), posthumously conferred
He was given posthumously the rank of Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade).
sen.cmt: スタイルを統一します。
sen.e: He was given posthumously the rank of Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade).

sen.j: 『日本書紀』が壬申の乱を記す中に尾張大隅の名は現れない。
sen.e: The name of OWARI no Osumi is not mentioned in the description of the Jinshin War in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
The name of OWARI no Osumi is not mentioned in the description of the Jinshin War in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
The name of OWARI no Osumi is not mentioned in the description of the Jinshin War in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 大隅の功績は、『続日本紀』天平宝字元年（757年）12月9日条にある。
sen.e: Osumi's great achievement is described in the article of December 9, 757 in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued).
Osumi's great achievement is described in the article of December 9, 757 in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued).
Osumi's great achievement is described in the article of December 9, 757 in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued).

sen.j: それによれば、大海人皇子（天武天皇）が吉野宮を脱して関東（この場合鈴鹿関の東）に行ったとき、尾治大隅は私邸を掃除して行宮に提供し、軍資を出して助けたという。
sen.e: According to it, when Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) left Yoshino no miya for Kanto region (in this case, east of Suzuka-no-seki Checkpoint), OWARI no Osumi cleaned up his private house to provide them with it as Angu (temporary lodging built to accommodate an Imperial visit) and helped them with war funds.

According to it, when Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) left Yoshino no miya (Yoshino Palace) for Kanto region (in this case, the east of Suzuka-no-seki Checkpoint), OWARI no Osumi cleaned up his private house to provide them with it as Angu (temporary lodging for emperor) and helped them with war funds.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: According to it, when Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu) left Yoshino no miya (Yoshino Palace) for Kanto region (in this case, the east of Suzuka-no-seki Checkpoint), OWARI no Osumi cleaned up his private house to provide them with it as Angu (temporary lodging for emperor) and helped them with war funds.

sen.j: 書紀にある大海人皇子の行動記録と照らし合わせてこの行宮の場所は美濃国の野上とするのが有力だ。
sen.e: In the light of behavioral record of Prince Oama in "Nihonshoki", it's generally understood that the Angu was located in Nogami in Mino Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the light of behavioral record of Prince Oama in "Nihonshoki", it's generally understood that the Angu was located in Nogami in Mino Province.
In the light of behavioral record of Prince Oama in "Nihonshoki", it's generally understood that the Angu was located in Nogami in Mino Province.

sen.j: しかし、これを伊勢国で鸕野讚良皇女（持統天皇）が住んだところとする説もある。
sen.e: However, it has been also said that the Angu was located in Ise province and Imperial princess Uno no Sarara (Emperor Jito) lived there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, it has been also said that the Angu was a residence in Ise Province Imperial Princess Uno no Sarara (the wife of Prince Oama, later became Empress Jito) had lived.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: However, it has been also said that the Angu was a residence in Ise Province Imperial Princess Uno no Sarara (the wife of Prince Oama, later became Empress Jito) had lived.

sen.j: 天武天皇13年（684年）12月2日に、尾張連など連姓の50氏が宿禰の姓を与えられた。
sen.e: On December 2, 684, Emperor Tenmu gave 50 clans having Muraji such as OWARI no Muraji kabane called Sukune (third highest of the eight hereditary titles).
On December 2, 684, fifty clans having the kabane of Muraji including OWARI no Muraji were given the new kabane of Sukune (third highest of the eight hereditary titles) by Emperor Tenmu.
On December 2, 684, fifty clans having the kabane of Muraji including OWARI no Muraji were given the new kabane of Sukune (third highest of the eight hereditary titles) by Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 持統天皇10年（696年）5月8日に、天皇は尾張宿禰大隅に直広肆の位と水田40町を与えた。
sen.e: On May 8, 696, Emperor Jito gave OWARI no Sukune Osumi Jikidaishi (the sixteenth grade of jikiko rank for vassals of the forty-eight grades of cap rank, which corresponds to Jugoinoge, Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade of Taiho Ritsuryo, Taiho Code) rank and 40 cho (unit of rice paddy area) of rice paddy.
sen.cmt: 町： cho (unit of rice paddy area) と訳しました。
sen.e: On May 8, 696, Empress Jito gave OWARI no Sukune Osumi the rank of Jikikoshi and rice fields 40 cho (396,720 square meters).
sen.cmt: 名詞読み間違い、訳語選択ミスがあります。他の記事でオリジナル文章の「位」の上に位階制度の説明がついているものがありました。この記事にはそれがありませんので、細かい説明は不要と思われます。
sen.e: On May 8, 696, Empress Jito gave OWARI no Sukune Osumi the rank of Jikikoshi and rice fields 40 cho (396,720 square meters).

sen.j: 霊亀2年（716年）に子の尾張稲置が大隅の功によって田を授かったとき、尾張宿禰大隅は贈従五位上と記される。
sen.e: In 716, when his son, OWARI no Inagi, was given rice fields for Osumi's service, OWARI no Sukune Osumi was recorded as Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), posthumously conferred.
In 716, when his son, OWARI no Inagi, was given rice fields for Osumi's service, OWARI no Sukune Osumi was recorded as Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), posthumously conferred.
In 716, when his son, OWARI no Inagi, was given rice fields for Osumi's service, OWARI no Sukune Osumi was recorded as Jugoinojo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade), posthumously conferred.

sen.j: 「贈」とあるため大隅がこのとき故人であったことがわかり、従五位上は大宝元年（701年）以降に用いられたから、没年は701年から716年の間と推測できる。
sen.e: With '贈 (posthumously conferred)' added, it's obvious that Osumi was deceased at that time, and it is presumable that the date of death is between 701 and 716 since Jugoinojo was used in and after 701.

With '贈 (posthumously conferred)' added, it's obvious that Osumi was deceased at that time, and it is presumable that the date of his death had been between 701 and 716 since the rank of Jugoinojo was used in and after 701.

With '贈 (posthumously conferred)' added, it's obvious that Osumi was deceased at that time, and it is presumable that the date of his death had been between 701 and 716 since the rank of Jugoinojo was used in and after 701.

sen.j: 後、天平宝字元年（757年）12月9日に、太政官は尾治大隅の功田40町の内容を論じ、それが上功にあたり、三世に功田を伝えると定めた。
sen.e: Later, on December 9, 757, Daijokan (Grand Council of State) discussed contents of 40 cho of OWARI no Osumi's Kuden (rice fields given to those who did meritorious deeds for the state) and decided that his deeds could be regarded as excellent service and the Kuden would be passed for three generations.

Later, on December 9, 757, Daijokan (Grand Council of State) discussed the background of Koden (rice field given to vassals or their families for their achievements) 40 cho which had been given for OWARI no Osumi's achievements, and decided that his deeds was Joko (first-grade achievement) and the Koden should be passed for three generations.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。「功田」は通常「こうでん」と読み、「上功」の読みとも通じるので「こうでん」にします。
sen.e: Later, on December 9, 757, Daijokan (Grand Council of State) discussed the background of Koden (rice field given to vassals or their families for their achievements) 40 cho which had been given for OWARI no Osumi's achievements, and decided that his deeds was Joko (first-grade achievement) and the Koden should be passed for three generations.
